result_equations.equation: sum vec F = 0 => vec v = const

explanation: Newton's three laws of motion form the foundation of classical mechanics. The First Law (Law of Inertia) states that objects maintain constant velocity unless acted upon by a net force, defining inertial reference frames. The Second Law establishes that net force equals mass times acceleration, or the rate of change of momentum, providing the fundamental equation of motion. The Third Law states that forces occur in equal and opposite pairs, ensuring momentum conservation. Together, these laws enable the prediction and analysis of motion for all macroscopic objects in the classical regime.

definitions.definition: Net force vector acting on an object.
Mass of the object (assumed constant for second_law).
Momentum vector of the object (vec p = m * vec v).
Force exerted by object A on object B.
Force exerted by object B on object A.

assumptions: Observations are made from inertial reference frames.
For the Second Law constant-mass form, mass remains constant during motion.
Forces are well-defined and can be measured or calculated.
The concept of inertial reference frames can be defined operationally.
Force can be defined as the rate of change of momentum.
Mass is an intrinsic property that may be constant or variable.
For isolated systems, total momentum is conserved.

derivation.description: The First Law establishes the existence of inertial reference frames where objects with no net force maintain constant velocity.
Mathematical expression: zero net force implies zero acceleration, hence constant velocity.
derivation.equation: sum vec F = 0 => (d vec v)/(dt) = 0 => vec v = const

derivation.description: The Second Law provides the quantitative relationship between force and motion.
Start with the most general form: force equals rate of change of momentum.
derivation.equation: vec F = (d vec p)/(dt) = (d(m * vec v))/(dt)

derivation.description: Apply product rule to differentiate momentum.
derivation.equation: vec F = m * (d vec v)/(dt) + vec v * (dm)/(dt)

derivation.description: For constant mass objects, the mass derivative term vanishes.
This yields the familiar F = ma form for constant mass systems.
derivation.equation: vec F = m * (d vec v)/(dt) = m * vec a

derivation.description: The Third Law emerges from momentum conservation in isolated systems.
derivation.equation: text(Third Law: Momentum conservation for isolated system)

derivation.description: For an isolated two-body system, total momentum is conserved.
The time derivative of total momentum equals the sum of individual force contributions.
By the Second Law, these are the net forces on each object.
For interaction forces only, this gives the action-reaction law.
derivation.equation: vec F_(BA) + vec F_(AB) = 0 => vec F_(AB) = -vec F_(BA)

code: t, m, v0 = sp.symbols('t m v0', real=True, positive=True)

# Test First Law: If net force is zero, velocity is constant
v = sp.integrate(a, t) + v0  # integrate to get velocity
assert sp.diff(v, t) == 0  # velocity is constant
assert v == v0  # velocity equals initial velocity
# Test Second Law: Verify F = dp/dt reduces to F = ma for constant mass
F_x_ma = m * sp.diff(v_x_t, t)  # F = ma
# Test Third Law: Action-reaction pairs sum to zero
